title: Drift velocity - ratio between wires X and Y

content.question: Two conducting wires, Wire <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> and Wire <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, have the same length and cross-sectional area but are made of different materials. The charge-carriers in the two wires are electrons, and have densities in wires <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> of \(4.0\times10^{22}\text{ C/}\text{m}^3\) and \(8.0\times10^{22}\text{ C/}\text{m}^3\), respectively. Wire <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> has three times the current of Wire <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator v sub Y, and denominator v sub X" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mfrac></math> of the average drift velocity <math alttext="v sub Y" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> in Wire <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> to the average drift velocity <math alttext="v sub X" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math> in Wire <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
